revision.comment: /* Rock, heavy metal, and jazz */ Minor spacing edit
revision.text:
{{About||the UK magazine|Guitarist (magazine)|the American magazine|Guitar Player}} {{pp-move-indef}} [[File:Guitarist Gretchen Menn 2017.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Guitarist performing at the 3rd Annual Malibu Guitar Festival 2017]] [[File:Guitar players in the city centre of Buenos Aires.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Guitar players in the city centre of [[Buenos Aires]].]] A '''guitarist''' (or a '''guitar player''') is a person who plays the [[guitar]]. Guitarists may play a variety of guitar family [[musical instrument|instruments]] such as [[classical guitar]]s, [[acoustic guitar]]s, [[electric guitar]]s, and [[bass guitar]]s. Some guitarists accompany themselves on the guitar by [[singing]] or playing the harmonica.
==Techniques== The guitarist may employ any of several methods for sounding the guitar, including finger picking, depending on the type of strings used (either [[Classical guitar strings|nylon]] or [[Steel-string acoustic guitar|steel]]), and including [[strumming]] with the fingers, or a [[guitar pick]] made of bone, horn, plastic, metal, felt, leather, or paper, and melodic [[flatpicking]] and [[fingerstyle guitar|finger-picking]].
The guitarist may also employ various methods for selecting notes and chords, including fingering, thumbing, the barre (a finger lying across many or all strings at a particular fret), and 'bottleneck' or steel-guitar slides, usually made of glass or metal. These left- and right-hand techniques may be intermixed in performance.
==Notable guitarists== [[File:Great guitarist montage.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Montage of guitarists. The guitarists pictured are named on the image page.]]
===Rock, heavy metal, and jazz=== Several [[magazine]]s and [[website]]s have compiled what they intend as lists of the greatest guitarists—for example ''The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time'' by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine, or ''100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time'' by ''[[Guitar World]]'' magazine.
;{{anchor|Rolling Stone}}''Rolling Stone'': In 2003, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine published a list called ''The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time''. This list included 100 guitarists whom the magazine editor [[David Fricke]] considered the best, with a brief introduction for each of them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231|title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''|date=2003-09-18|accessdate=2011-12-01}}</ref> The first in this list is the American guitarist [[Jimi Hendrix]] introduced by [[Pete Townshend]], guitarist for [[The Who]], who was, in his turn, ranked at #50 in the list.
:In describing the list to readers, Paul MacInnes from British newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote, "Surprisingly enough for an American magazine, the top 10 is fair jam-packed with Yanks," though he also noted three exceptions in the top 10.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2007/feb/13/whoarethe100greatestguita|title=Who are the 100 greatest guitarists of all time?|first=Paul|last=MacInnes|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=2007-02-13|accessdate=2009-11-18 | location=London}}</ref> The online magazine ''[[Blogcritics]]'' criticized the list for introducing some {{which|date=May 2010}} allegedly undeserving guitarists while forgetting some artists the writer considered perhaps more worthy, such as [[Johnny Marr]], [[Al Di Meola]], [[Phil Keaggy]] or [[John Petrucci]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogcritics.org/the-top-100-guitarists-according-to/ |publisher=''[[Blogcritics]]'' |title=The Top 100 Guitarists According to Rolling Stone |author=The Theory |date=2003-08-28 |accessdate=2009-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605091245/http://blogcritics.org/the-top-100-guitarists-according-to/ |archivedate=5 June 2013 }}</ref>
:In 2011, ''Rolling Stone'' updated the list, which this time was chosen by a panel of guitarists and other experts with the top 5 consisting of [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Jimmy Page]], [[Keith Richards]] and [[Jeff Beck]]. Artists who had not been included in the previous list were added. [[Rory Gallagher]], for example, was ranked in 57th place.<ref name="Greatest guitarist Rory Gallagher">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/rory-gallagher-19691231|title=100 Greatest Guitarists: Rory Gallagher|publisher=Rolling Stone magazine|accessdate=31 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712063544/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/rory-gallagher-19691231|archive-date=23 November 2011|dead-url=yes}}</ref> :''The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time'' is mentioned in many biographies about artists who appear in the list.<ref>{{cite book|title=How to Succeed As a Female Guitarist: The Essential Guide for Working in a Male-dominated Industry|first=Vivian|last= Clement|page=1|publisher=Alfred Publishing|year=2007|isbn=0-7390-4304-8}}</ref>
;''Guitar World'': ''[[Guitar World]]'', a monthly music magazine devoted to the guitar, also published their list of 100 greatest guitarists in the book ''Guitar World Presents the 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time from the Pages of Guitar World Magazine''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Guitar World Presents the 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time from the Pages of Guitar World Magazine|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|author=Jeff Kitts, Brad Tolinski|year=2002|isbn=0-634-04619-5}}</ref> Different from the ''Rolling Stone'' list, which listed guitarists in descending order, ''Guitar World'' divided guitarists by [[music genre]]—such as "Lords of Hard Rock" for [[hard rock]] artists or "Jazzmen" for [[jazz]] players. Despite the appearance in other magazines like ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'',<ref>''Billboard'', vol. 117, n° 49, pp. 67</ref> this publication by ''Guitar World'' was criticized for including no female musicians within its selection.<ref>{{cite book|title=Gender in the music industry: Rock, discourse and girl power|page=38|first=Marion|last= Leonard|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|year=2007|isbn=0-7546-3862-6}}</ref> However, ''Guitar World'' recently published a list of "Eight Amazing Female Acoustic Players," including [[Kaki King]], [[Muriel Anderson]] and [[Sharon Isbin]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Eight Amazing Female Acoustic Guitar Players|url = http://www.guitarworld.com/acoustic-nation-eight-amazing-female-acoustic-players|accessdate = 2015-10-04}}</ref>
;''TIME'' and others: Following the death of [[Les Paul]], ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' website presented their list of 10 greatest artists in [[electric guitar]]. As in ''Rolling Stone'' magazine's list, Jimi Hendrix was chosen as the greatest guitarist followed by [[Slash (musician)|Slash]] from [[Guns N'Roses|Guns 'N' Roses]], [[B.B. King]], [[Keith Richards]], [[Jimmy Page]], and [[Eric Clapton]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,1916544_1921910,00.html|title=The 10 Greatest Electric-Guitar Players|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]''|accessdate=2009-11-18 | date=2009-08-14}}</ref> ''[[Gigwise.com]]'', an online music magazine, also ranks Jimi Hendrix as the greatest guitarist ever, followed by Jimmy Page, B.B. King, Keith Richards and [[Kirk Hammett]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gigwise.com/news/40852/The-50-Greatest-Guitarists-Ever|title=The 50 Greatest Guitarists... Ever!|publisher=''[[Gigwise.com]]''|accessdate=2010-01-14}}</ref>
===Other genres=== There are many [[List of classical guitarists|classical guitarists]] listed as ''notable'' in their respective epochs.
In recent decades, the most "notable classical and cross genre" guitarist was [[Paco de Lucía]], one of the first [[flamenco guitarists]] to have successfully crossed over into other genres of music such as classical and jazz. [[Richard Chapman (musician)|Richard Chapman]] and [[Eric Clapton]], authors of ''Guitar: Music, History, Players'', describe de Lucía as a "titanic figure in the world of [[flamenco guitar]]",<ref>*{{cite book|last1=Chapman|first1=Richard|last2=Clapton|first2=Eric|title=Guitar: music, history, players|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hLUXAQAAIAAJ|year=2000|publisher=Dorling Kindersley Pub.|isbn=978-0-7894-5963-3|page=40|ref=harv}}</ref> and Dennis Koster, author of ''Guitar Atlas, Flamenco'', has referred to de Lucía as "one of history's greatest guitarists.".<ref name="Koster2002">{{cite book|last=Koster|first=Dennis|title=Guitar Atlas, Flamenco|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l8SMixi1mbQC&pg=PA5|accessdate=4 March 2013|date=1 June 2002|publisher=Alfred Music Publishing|isbn=978-0-7390-2478-2|page=5}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/27/arts/music/paco-de-lucia-flamenco-guitarist-dies-at-66.html?_r=0|title=Paco de Lucía, Master Flamenco Guitarist, Dies at 66|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{wiktionary|guitarist}} *{{Commons category-inline|Guitarists}}
{{Guitars}}
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:Guitarists| ]] [[Category:Occupations in music]]

'''Hanne Tott''' or Tod, also called Price and Kuhn (14 February 1771 - August 15,1826), was a Danish [[circus]] artist and circus manager. She and her family played an important part in the history of the circus in [[Scandinavia]]. She should not be confused with her sister-in-law [[Rosalia Price]], also called Madame Price.
She was born to Stephen and Hanne Todd and married in 1791 to the British circus manager [[James Price (1761-1805)]]. She and her spouse toured Scandinavia, [[Denmark]], [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]] with their circus. In 1793-94, they performed at [[Stenborg Theatre]] in [[Stockholm]]. From 1795, they regularly performed in [[Copenhagen]] during the summer and toured Denmark and Norway during the winter. They were permitted to found a permanent stage in Copenhagen in 1801. She became manager after the death of her spouse in 1805. In 1810, she married [[Frantz Joseph Kuhn]] (1783-1832), with whom she shared her position as manager.
== References == * Wåhlberg, Per Arne: ''Cirkus i Sverige : bidrag till vårt lands kulturhistoria.'' Stockholm Carlsson 1992. {{ISBN|91-7798-591-5}} * Davidsen, Fra det gamle Kongens Kjøbenhavn II, 181 ff. Museum 1894, I, 184 f. * http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Kunst_og_kultur/Cirkus/Artist/James_Price

{{Infobox television | show_name = Hubworld | image = | caption = | genre = | runtime = 22 minutes (Approx.) | creator = | executive_producer = Kathy Samuels | producer = [[Hasbro|Hasbro Studios]]{{cite web|url=http://press.discovery.com/us/hub/press-releases/2010/hub-adds-new-pop-culture-series-hubworld-netwo-885/|accessdate=May 30, 2011|title=The Hub adds new pop culture series "Hubworld" to network's original programming line-up|author=Mark Kern}} | company = [[Hasbro Studios]]
Natural 9 Entertainment | presenter = [[Justin Kredible|Justin "Kredible" Willman]] | country = United States | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[high definition television|HD]]) | network = [[Discovery Family|The Hub]] | distributor = | first_aired = {{Start date|2010|11|5}} | last_aired = {{End date|2011|10|29}} | num_episodes = 52 | num_seasons = 2 | followed_by = | list_episodes = | website = | website_title = }} '''''Hubworld''''' is a defunct American [[Children's television series|children's]] [[news magazine]] [[television series]] on [[Discovery Family|The Hub]]. It was produced by Natural 9 Entertainment with an association with [[Hasbro Studios]]. The program premiered on November 5, 2010{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2010/10/28/the-hub-announces-premiere-date-for-original-series-hubworld/70076/|accessdate=May 30, 2011|title=The Hub Announces Premiere Date for Original Series 'Hubworld'|author=Robert Seidman}} and was hosted by actor/magician [[Justin Kredible|Justin "Kredible" Willman]]. The program's premiere date was delayed from The Hub's launch date on October 10, 2010, to November due to unknown factors. ==Program summary== ''Hubworld'' provided looks at current programs then on The Hub, including shows such as ''[[Family Game Night (TV series)|Family Game Night]]'', the network's animated franchises such as ''[[G.I. Joe: Renegades]]'', ''[[Transformers: Prime]]'', ''[[Dan Vs.]]'' and ''[[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic]]''. Segments included Willman's comedic news and current events monologue called "Back it Up", and "Hub Happenings", which involved Willman riffing on short clips of Hub programming. Other segments included interviews of current pop music stars, celebrities and sports stars, press line interviews at film premieres or [[Film promotion|junket interviews]] of film stars, and features involving children doing good in their communities and throughout the world. An ending segment features musician Danny Tieger singing a song about the news events of the week in a segment called "Just to Let You Know News Jam". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1815070}} {{Hasbro Studios}} [[Category:2010 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:2011 American television series endings]] [[Category:Infotainment]] [[Category:Television series by Hasbro Studios]] [[Category:American children's reality television series]] {{US-child-tv-prog-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = Ines Torelli |other names = |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1931|6|14}} |birth_place = [[St. Gallen]], [[Canton of St. Gallen]], [[Switzerland]] |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = Comedian, radio personality, stage, television and film actress |nationality = Swiss |spouse = Edi Baur (1991–2009) |children = |years_active = since 1954 |residence = [[Rose Bay, Nova Scotia]],<ref name="inestorelli-rosebay">{{cite web|url=https://www.glueckspost.ch/leute/ines-torelli-als-edi-starb-hielt-ich-seine-hand/|title=Ines Torelli: Als Edi starb, hielt ich seine Hand|publisher=glueckspost.ch|author=H. Elias Fröhlich and B. Torricelli|language=German|date=2009-10-28|accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref> [[Canada]] |notable_works = |awards = }} '''Ines Torelli''' (née '''Ines Stierli''', born 14 June 1931) is a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] comedian, radio personality, and stage, voice and film actress starring usually in Swiss German language cinema and television and stage productions.
== Early life and education == Born and raised in [[St. Gallen]], [[Canton of St. Gallen]] in Switzerland to Walter Stierli,<ref name="hds">{{cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D9568.php|title=Torelli, Ines|publisher=HDS|author=Hansruedi Lerch|language=German|date=2011-07-27|accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref> Ines Torelli worked as a domestic helper in 1948/50, the so-called ''Welschlandjahr'' which at that time usually teenage women absolved in western Switzerland (''Welschland'') to improve the knowledge of the French language. As an autodidact Torelli got a first chance in the "Cabaret Rüeblisaft" those member she became between 1954 and 1956. Subsequently, she was engaged by the [[Cabaret Federal]] in Zürich, followed by various tours along with [[Schaggi Streuli]], among others in "Sie und de Chef".<ref name="theaterlexikon-inestorelli">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Ines_Torelli|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Ines Torelli|author=Thomas Hostettler|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref> On [[Theater am Hechtplatz]] Torelli embodied the title roles in various musicals,<ref name="theaterlexikon-hechtplatz">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Theater_am_Hechtplatz,_Z%C3%BCrich_ZH|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Theater am Hechtplatz, Zürich ZH|author=Tanja Stenzl|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-26}}</ref> so in 1965 in "Bibi Balù", in 1967 in "Golden Girl", in 1968 "Pfui Martina" and in 1972 in "Viva Banana". In 1968 she starred alongside [[Ruedi Walter]] and [[Margrit Rainer]] as ''Olly Moreen'' in ''[[Die kleine Niederdorf-Oper]]'' at the Corso Theater in Zürich.<ref name="theaterlexikon-ruediwalter">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Ruedi_Walter|title=Ruedi Walter|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|author=|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref><ref name="theaterlexikon-margritrainer">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Margrti_Rainer|title=Margrit Rainer|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|author=|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-08-22}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="theaterlexikon-inestorelli"/>
== Theater, cabaret, voice acting, television and film == Ines Torelli played in various farces at [[Bernhard Theater Zürich]],<ref name="theaterlexikon-bernhard">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Bernhard-Theater,_Z%C3%BCrich_ZH|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Bernhard-Theater, Zürich ZH|author=|language=German|date=2013-11-22|accessdate=2015-09-24}}</ref> as partner of [[Jörg Schneider]] and [[Paul Bühlmann]],<ref name="theaterlexikon-jörgschneider">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/J%C3%B6rg_Schneider|title=Jörg Schneider|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|author=|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref><ref name="theaterlexikon-bühlmann">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Paul_Bühlmann|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Paul Bühlmann|author=|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-24}}</ref> so among other things in 1968 in "Mademoiselle Pepsi", "Der keusche Lebemann" in 1972, in 1974 in "Die Schwindelfiliale" and in 1976 in "Der fidele Casimir". Unsatisfied by these roles, in 1977 she starred, with artistic but not a commercial success, in the solo program "Torelli total". Nevertheless, she continued to play in comedies like "Potz Millione", with Rainer and Walter and directed by [[Inigo Gallo]],<ref name="theaterlexikon-jörgschneider"/> on [[Bernhard-Theater]] in 1979/80 that also became a big tour success, and in 1982 in Yves Jamiaque's "Acapulco, Madame" in the dialect version of Schneider and directed by Gallo at the [[Theater am Hechtplatz]].<ref name="theaterlexikon-inestorelli"/>
Torelli had also great success and was very popular as a chanson singer, so with "De Gigi vo Arosa" and as ''Iduna'' in Burkhard's "Der schwarze Hecht" at the ''Corso Theater'' in 1981. From 1986 to 1994 she was the head of the [[Zürcher Märchenbühne]], and besides of her own dialect version of ''Räuber Hotzenplotz'' and [[Jörg Schneider]]'s 1994 fairytale edition of "Das brave kleine Schneiderlein", Torelli staged among others again with Schneider in numerous musicals with children.<ref name="theaterlexikon-inestorelli"/>
She also became popular by numerous radio appearances and roles in Swiss and German films, among them in ''Oberstadtgass'' in 1956 and in one episode of ''[[Fascht e Familie]]''. Beside the stage and television and film, again with Jörg Schneider and Paul Bühlmann, Ines Torelli became also very popular in the German speaking area by fairytale-radio plays records.<ref name="srf-archivperlen">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/unterhaltung/people/schweiz/vip-archiv/archiv-perlen-die-schoensten-joerg-schneider-momente|title=Archiv-Perlen: Die schönsten Jörg-Schneider-Momente|publisher=[[Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen]] SRF|author=Karl Baldinger|language=German|date=2015-08-22|accessdate=2015-08-24}}</ref><ref name="zol-20150822">{{cite web|url=http://www.zol.ch/bezirk-hinwil/wetzikon/joerg-schneider-ist-tot/story/13778801|title=Jörg Schneider ist tot|publisher=[[Zürcher Oberländer]]|author=|language=German|date=2015-08-22|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref>
In 1993 she emigrated with her husband to Canada to reside on the [[Lunenburg, Nova Scotia|Lunenburg]] peninsula on the east coast of Canada. In 1996 they acquired an empty factory and rebuilt it into the ''Starlight Theatre'' to house up to 500 spectator seats. End of 1998 the financially unsuccessful private theater had to close.<ref name="theaterlexikon-inestorelli"/>
== Personal life == Ines Torelli is citizen of the [[Municipalities of the canton of Zürich|municipality]] of [[Wettswil am Albis]] in the [[Canton of Zürich]] and of [[Aristau]] in the [[Canton of Aargau]]. In 1991 she married Edi Baur, a Swiss theatre director and actor,<ref name="hds"/> who died on 14 October 2009.<ref name="inestorelli-rosebay"/> Although she is living in Canada since 1996, the friendship with [[Jörg Schneider]] survided.<ref name="srf">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/unterhaltung/people/schweiz/ueberraschungsanruf-ines-torelli-ruehrt-joerg-schneider-zu-traenen|title=Überraschungsanruf: Ines Torelli rührt Jörg Schneider zu Tränen |publisher=srf.ch|author=|language=German|date=2015-01-18|accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref>
== Filmography == * 1995: ''[[Fascht e Familie]]'' (Television series, 1 episode) * 1981: ''Potz Millione'' (stage, broadcast on Swiss television) * 1975: ''De grotzepuur'' * 1971: ''Professor Sound und die Pille - Die unwahrscheinliche Geschichte einer Erfindung'' (Television film) * 1969: ''Pfarrer Iseli'' * 1968: ''Die sechs Kummerbuben'' * 1962: ''Chikita'' * 1959: ''Café Odeon'' * 1957: ''Bäckerei Zürrer'' * 1956: ''Oberstadtgass''
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{official website|http://www.inestorelli.ch}} {{de icon}} * {{HDS|9568|Ines Torelli|author=Hansruedi Lerch|date=27 July 2011}} * {{IMDb name|id=0867928|name=Ines Torelli}} * [http://www.srf.ch/suche?q=Ines+Torelli Ines Torelli on the website of the Swiss national television SRF] {{de icon}}

page.title: List of Luxembourgish submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} The Grand Duchy of [[Luxembourg]] has submitted films for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] since 1997. The Foreign Language Film award is handed out annually by the [[United States]] [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] to a [[feature length|feature-length]] motion picture produced outside the United States that contains primarily non-[[English language|English]] dialogue.{{cite web|title=Rule Thirteen: Special Rules for the Foreign Language Film Award |work=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/rules/86/rule13.html |accessdate=2013-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822101822/http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/rules/86/rule13.html |archivedate=22 August 2013 |df= }} {{as of|2018}}, fifteen Luxembourgian films have been submitted for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film, but none have yet been nominated for an Academy Award. ==Submissions== The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has invited the film industries of various countries to submit their best film for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film since 1956. The Foreign Language Film Award Committee oversees the process and reviews all the submitted films. Following this, they vote via [[secret ballot]] to determine the five nominees for the award. Below is a list of the films that have been submitted by Luxembourg for review by the Academy for the award by year and the respective Academy Awards ceremony. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:98%; background:#fff;" |- ! Year
(Ceremony) !! Film title used in nomination !! Original title !! Languages !! Director !! Result |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[1997 in film|1997]]
[[70th Academy Awards|(70th)]] | ''[[Women (1997 film)|Women]]'' | ''Elles'' | [[French language|French]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | {{sortname|Luís Galvão|Teles}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[1998 in film|1998]]
[[71st Academy Awards|(71st)]] | ''[[Back in Trouble]]'' | ''Back in Trouble'' | [[Lëtzebuergesch]], [[German language|German]] | {{sortname|Andy|Bausch}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2002 in film|2002]]
[[75th Academy Awards|(75th)]] | ''[[Dead Man's Hand (2002 film)|Dead Man's Hand]]'' | ''Petites misères'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Philippe|Boon}} & [[Laurent Brandenbourger]] | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2003 in film|2003]]
[[76th Academy Awards|(76th)]] | ''[[I Always Wanted to Be a Saint]]'' | ''J'ai toujours voulu être une sainte'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Geneviève|Mersch}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2005 in film|2005]]
[[78th Academy Awards|(78th)]] | ''[[Renart the Fox]]'' | ''Le Roman de Renart'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Thierry|Schiel}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2006 in film|2006]]
[[79th Academy Awards|(79th)]] | ''[[Your Name is Justine]]'' | ''Your Name is Justine'' | [[Polish language|Polish]], [[English language|English]] | {{sortname|Franco|de Pena}} | {{no|Disqualified}} {{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/awardcentral_article/VR1117953559.html?nav=news&categoryid=1985&cs=1 | work=Variety | title=Lux out of 'Name' game | first=Melanie | last=Goodfellow | date=2006-11-08}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2007 in film|2007]]
[[80th Academy Awards|(80th)]] | ''[[Perl oder Pica|Little Secrets]]'' | ''Perl oder Pica'' | [[Lëtzebuergesch]] | {{sortname|Pol|Cruchten}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2008 in film|2008]]
[[81st Academy Awards|(81st)]] | ''[[Nuits d'Arabie]]'' | ''Nuits d'Arabie'' | [[French language|French]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | {{sortname|Paul|Kieffer}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2009 in film|2009]]
[[82nd Academy Awards|(82nd)]] | ''[[Refractaire]]'' | ''Réfractaire'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Nicolas|Steil}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2013 in film|2013]]
[[86th Academy Awards|(86th)]] | ''[[Blind Spot (2012 film)|Blind Spot]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.lequotidien.lu/culture/48213.html |title="Doudege Wénkel" aux Oscars |accessdate=2013-08-30 |work=Le Quotidien |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215154737/http://www.lequotidien.lu/culture/48213.html |archivedate=15 December 2013 |df= }} | ''Doudege Wénkel'' | [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]] | {{sortname|Christophe|Wagner}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2014 in film|2014]]
[[87th Academy Awards|(87th)]] | ''[[Never Die Young (film)|Never Die Young]]''{{cite web |url=http://www.wort.lu/en/culture/cinema-harrowing-true-story-from-luxembourg-is-oscar-hopeful-53ff0805b9b398870805bcd8 |title=Harrowing true story from Luxembourg is Oscar hopeful |accessdate=28 August 2014 |work=Luxembourg Wort}} | ''Never Die Young'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Pol|Cruchten}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2015 in film|2015]]
[[88th Academy Awards|(88th)]] | ''[[Baby(a)lone]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.cineuropa.org/nw.aspx?t=newsdetail&l=en&did=297617 |title=Baby(A)lone is Luxembourg's Oscars hopeful |work=Cineuropa |date=24 August 2015 |accessdate=24 August 2015}} | ''Baby(a)lone'' | [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]] | {{sortname|Donato|Rotunno}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2016 in film|2016]]
[[89th Academy Awards|(89th)]] | ''[[Voices from Chernobyl (film)|Voices from Chernobyl]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.wort.lu/en/culture/foreign-language-film-category-from-chernobyl-to-hollywood-57d27065ac730ff4e7f66246 |title="Voices from Chernobyl" to represent Luxembourg |work=[[Luxemburger Wort]] |date=9 September 2016 |accessdate=9 September 2016}} | ''La supplication'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Pol|Cruchten}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2017 in film|2017]]
[[90th Academy Awards|(90th)]] | ''[[Barrage (film)|Barrage]]''{{cite web|url=http://delano.lu/d/detail/news/drama-barrage-represent-lux-2018-oscars/155120 |title=Drama "Barrage" to represent Lux. at 2018 Oscars |work=Delano |first=Jess |last=Bauldry |date=8 September 2017 |accessdate=8 September 2017}} | ''Barrage'' | [[French language|French]] | {{sortname|Laura|Schroeder}} | {{nom|Not Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[2018 in film|2018]]
[[91st Academy Awards|(91st)]] | ''[[Gutland (film)|Gutland]]''{{cite web|url=https://luxtimes.lu/culture-life/34874-gutland-selected-as-luxembourg-pick-for-oscars |title=Gutland selected as Luxembourg pick for Oscars |work=[[Luxembourg Times]] |first=Hannah |last=Brenton |date=6 September 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} | ''Gutland'' | [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]], [[German language|German]] | {{sortname|Govinda|Van Maele}} | {{center|TBD}} |} Because of Luxembourg's small size, many of the submitted films were co-productions with neighboring countries. [[AMPAS]] disqualified ''Your Name is Justine'' in 2006, arguing that Luxembourg did not have sufficient artistic control over the muilti-national film, which was directed by a Poland-based Venezuelan director, set in Germany and Poland, funded primarily by Luxembourg, and shot mostly in Polish and English. The film was originally considered to represent Poland, but it did not make Poland's four-film shortlist [https://archive.is/20120720075610/http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/wiadomosci/1,55670,3642251.html ] and it was subsequently selected to represent Luxembourg. Luxembourg's first submission, ''Elles'' also straddled the nationality guidelines. Directed by a Portuguese and set in [[Lisbon]], the film was primarily in French, and featured a diverse lead cast from France, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland, and the US, but not Luxembourg. ''Dead Man's Hand'' was a minority Luxembourg production, which actually represented [[Cinema of Belgium|Belgium]] at several film festivals.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfs.org.sg/event.php?id=79|title=Singapore Film Society|website=Singapore Film Society|accessdate=6 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113084348/http://sfs.org.sg/event.php?id=79|archive-date=13 January 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} All other films were directed by native-born Luxembourgian directors. Of Luxembourg's nine accepted submissions, two were light comedies (1998 and 2002), two were contemporary dramas (1997 and 2003) one was an animated film (2005), one was a thriller (2008,) one was a crime drama (2013,) and two were period dramas set in the 1940s (2009) and 1960s (2007). ==See also== *[[List of Academy Award winners and nominees for Best Foreign Language Film]] *[[List of Academy Award-winning foreign language films]] *[[Cinema of Luxembourg]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080707023727/http://www.oscars.org/awardsdatabase/ The Official Academy Awards Database] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080622050250/http://www.oscars.org/impc_site2/index.html The Motion Picture Credits Database] *[https://www.imdb.com/Sections/Awards/Academy_Awards_USA/ IMDb Academy Awards Page] {{Academy Award for Best Foreign Film submissions}} {{Academy Awards}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Luxembourgian Submissions For The Academy Award For Best Foreign Language Film}} [[Category:Best Foreign Language Film Academy Award submissions by country|Luxembourg]] [[Category:Lists of Luxembourgian media|Academy Award]] [[Category:Cinema of Luxembourg]]

{{About|a toy robot|Transformers Omnibots|Omnibots}} [[File:Omnibot 2000-P3170191-gradient.jpg|thumb|The Omnibot 2000]]
The '''Omnibot''' (オムニボット) is a toy [[robot]] originally manufactured by [[Tomy]] in the mid-1980s. The name then came to apply to the successful line of robots manufactured by the company. The initial Omnibot was announced with expectations of restoring popular interest in robots, at a time when it was becoming obvious that robots with advanced [[AI]] such as [[R2-D2]] were still a long way away. A more advanced version of the Omnibot was called the Omnibot 2000 and did not have a plastic bubble over its head. With the success of the Omnibots, the Omnibot range quickly expanded. After the [[North American video game crash of 1983]] and its debilitating effect on the entire nascent [[home electronics]] industry, the Omnibot faded away but it was revived in the early 2000s. The latest version of the Omnibot is the i-SOBOT.<ref>{{cite journal|date=February 1985|title=Tomy's Omnibot|journal=Adweek: MAC/Western advertising news|volume=35|issue=1-32|page=4}}</ref>
[[File:Omnibot 2000-P3170194.jpg|thumb|upright|The cassette tape player of an Omnibot 2000]] Both the Omnibot and the more advanced Omnibot 2000 had a [[cassette tape]] player built into the chest area of the robot, which slid out like a drawer to reveal the cassette and could record and play back sequences of commands, as well as regular audio recordings. The built in digital clock with timers and alarms allowed the playback of movement recordings at specified times, such as moving into the bedroom in the morning. Both robots were able to broadcast speech from the remote control handset through a speaker on the robot, and both were shipped with a cardboard "home" base which was suggested to be taped to the floor and used as a reference point for programming.<ref>{{cite journal|date=April 1986|title=Omnibot Grows Up|journal=Popular Science|page=79}}</ref>
[[File:Omnibot 2000-P3170193.jpg|thumb|Detail of the claw system]] Both Omnibot and the Omnibot 2000 could carry light objects. The Omnibot carried a specially made tray which slotted into its claws, and the Omnibot 2000 had a tray which slotted into its motorised "accessory panel", allowing the tray to revolve cups and glasses into the reach of the arm.
The Omnibot 2000 was 25 inches tall, powered by a 6-volt [[lead–acid battery]] and two [[AA batteries]]. Its right arm was controllable. The user could control its shoulder, elbow, wrist and fingers, the left arm being a poseable "dummy".
Unfortunately, losing the remote control unit for an Omnibot meant that the robot was virtually useless outside of the clock and cassette deck based functions.
Two lesser known robots in the Omnibot range were the Omnibot OOM and the Omniwagon. The Omnibot OOM was shaped like a standard Omnibot except with the addition of a spherical head, its remote controller including a basic form of [[Speech recognition|voice-control]]. The Omniwagon was merely a remote controlled drive unit and wheels from an omnibot with a flat surface on top to carry objects.<ref>{{cite journal|date=1985|title=Omnibot|journal=Robotics Age|volume=7|page=43}}</ref>
==Related Robots==
===Omnibot OOM / Hearoid=== The Omnibot OOM (later released in North America as the "Hearoid") was closely based on the standard Omnibot. Changes included a more anthropomorphic head design, remotely controlled light-up eyes that acted rather like headlights, and a more sophisticated remote controller that included primitive voice control.
===Robie Sr.=== Radio Shack retailed a version of the Omnibot named the Robie Sr.. Made by Tomy in Japan, these were essentially a standard Omnibot, but with the dome-shaped head replaced by the more anthropomorphic head of the Omnibot OOM / Hearoid, and the sound is different compared to the original Omnibot.
===Omnibot Jr. "Charmmy"/Robie Jr.=== The Omnibot Jr., also known as the "Charmmy", was a 10.5 inches tall remote controlled robot with an attachable tray, featuring styling reminiscent of the original Omnibot. Simultaneously released by Radio Shack as the Robie Jr., Omnibot Jr. included a microphone on either side of the robot's head that allowed it to hear an ultrasonic sound emitted by the remote controller. The dual microphones allowed Charmmy to determine the rough direction of the controller, and navigate to its location - sometimes even around corners. The Omnibot Jr. was also equipped with a bump sensor that allowed it to navigate around objects, and this sensor was also used along with sensors in the arms to trigger several recorded announcements should the robot bump into an object or an item be placed on the tray.
===Verbot/KI*KU*ZO=== The classic Omnibot had a cheaper, smaller cousin known as the Verbot, known in its native Japan as the KI*KU*ZO. At nine inches tall, the Verbot was the mid-sized option compared to the smaller Dingbot and the larger Omnibot. It was somewhat similar to the Omnibot in appearance but was much more limited in features. The Verbot also came with a wireless remote control that could operate the robot through voice commands. Up to eight commands could be programmed. The Verbot could move forward and backward, left and right, on command. The Verbot was also able to pick up small objects, a feature many toy robots of the era lacked. The robot expressed some personality by blinking and smiling. Disadvantages common to the Verbot were that it was quite noisy, reprogramming was necessary every time the robot was powered up again, and as with all of the Omnibot series its white plastic body would turn yellow if left in the sun. The Verbot was actually quite complex, utilizing a single motor for all its movements and an intricate set of gears for picking up objects. Programming Verbot was accomplished by pushing one of the buttons on its front panel and holding it down while the corresponding action was spoken into the remote control's microphone and then releasing the button. As with most Omnibots, losing the remote meant the robot could not be used to full capacity, but some hobbyists have modified cheap 1980s [[walkie-talkie]]s for inputting voice commands.
==Omnibots today== [[File:I-SOBOT-Wikipedia.jpg|thumb|upright|Japanese i-SOBOT, November 2007 model.]] In recent times, many hobbyists have turned to hacking, tweaking and improving their Omnibots. Commonly added features are IR Sensors, video cameras, speech recognition chips, stronger motors, microcontrollers, sonars and other advanced enhancements that would not have been possible in the 80s.
In the early 2000s, a gutted Omnibot was used as part of a contestant on the [[United States|US]] television show [[Battlebots]]. The robot, named [[Dr. Inferno Jr.]] (an updated version of another combat robot that used a gutted Omnibot) won several awards in the competition's "Lightweight Division". The Omnibot on top of the drivetrain had no dome on top, and its arms were replaced with twin saws.
===i-SOBOT=== In 2006, shortly after the merger of Tomy and Takara, the company first unveiled a prototype for a new Omnibot, initially called "Omnibot 2007: i-SOBOT" but which has since been officially named, "Omnibot 17μ: i-SOBOT." ("μ" is the Greek letter "mu" symbolizing micron, referring to the specs of the servo motors) in Japan and simply "i-SOBOT" in the U.S. market. i-SOBOT was scheduled to go on sale in Japan in October 2007 (Japanese language with blue and white color), but an English language, black and grey version went on sale first in the U.S., in September, 2007. Reportedly, a European version will go on the market in 2008.
i-SOBOT, which has been certified by Guinness World Records as "the world's smallest humanoid robot in production" is equipped with 17 proprietary servo-motors and can be controlled by an IR remote controller and also via voice commands. It is capable of speaking hundreds of words and phrases and has nearly 200 pre-programmed actions, plus allows additional programming by the user via the remote control. The retail price is approximately ¥30,000 in Japan and $350 in the U.S. i-SOBOT is fully bi-pedal. In 2013 the new robot i-SODOG will come out from Tomy.
==See also== {{Portal|Robotics|Toys}} * [[Topo (robot)|Topo]], a contemporary of Omnibot, aimed at the consumer and educational market. * [['80s Robot]], a similar looking Muppet character. * [[Compact Cassette]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.isobotrobot.com Official TOMY i-SOBOT website] *[http://www.theoldrobots.com/tomybot.html theoldrobots.com website]

{{Infobox film | name = Panfilov's 28 Men | image = Panfilov's_28_Men.jpg | image size = | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | film name = 28 панфиловцев | director = Kim Druzhinin
[[Andrey Shalopa]] {{cite web|url=http://28panfilovcev.com/|title=28 панфиловцев|website=28panfilovcev.com|accessdate=6 October 2017}} {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PK7ISg6Vx_I|title=Andrey Shalopa |date=|website=Youtube.com|accessdate=6 October 2017}} | producer = Anton Yudintsev
[[Andrey Shalopa]] | screenplay = [[Andrey Shalopa]] | based on = | starring = Aleksandr Ustyugov
Yakov Kucherevskiy
Azamat Nigmanov
Oleg Fyodorov
Aleksey Morozov | music = Mikhail Kostylev | cinematography = Nikita Rozhdestvenskiy | editing = | studio = Panfilov's Twenty Eight
[[Gaijin Entertainment]] | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2016|11|24|Russia}} | runtime = 105 minutes | country = Russia | language = Russian
German | budget = $1,700,000 | gross = $6,346,968 (January 2017)
₽385 million [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]]
₽366.6 million rubles (Russia)
₸61.3 million tenge ([[Kazakhstan]]) }} '''''Panfilov's 28 Men''''' ({{lang-ru|28 панфиловцев}}, [[Transliteration|translit.]] ''28 panfilovtsev'') is a 2016 [[war film]] based on a [[Propaganda in the Soviet Union|Soviet propaganda]] legend about a group of soldiers – [[Panfilov's Twenty-Eight Guardsmen]] – heroically halting and destroying German tanks headed for Moscow before all perishing together on the battlefield.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37595972|title=Putin backs WW2 myth in new Russian film|last=Bone|first=Harry|date=2016-10-11|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-05-21|language=en-GB}} It is set in the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front of World War II]] and covers the [[8th Guards Rifle Division]] operations during the 1941 [[Battle of Moscow]].{{cite web|url=http://tengrinews.kz/kazakhstan_news/vnuchka-panfilova-razgovoryi-o-nenastoyaschem-podvige-28-gvardeytsev-amoralnyi-237850/|title=Внучка Панфилова: Разговоры о ”ненастоящем” подвиге 28 гвардейцев аморальны|website=Tengrinews.kz|accessdate=6 October 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/oct/11/vladimir-putin-panfilovs-28-men-film-screening-astana-kazakhstan|title=Russian film about disputed wartime action wins Putin's support|last=Pulver|first=Andrew|date=2016-10-11|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-05-21|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} On DVD, it is also known as '''Battle for Moscow'''. The film is directed by Kim Druzhinin and Andrey Shalopa, produced by Panfilov's Twenty Eight and [[Gaijin Entertainment]]. Initially the film used crowdfunding, later it has been financially supported by Russian and [[Kazakhstan]] governments and Gaijin Entertainment game development company. The premiere took place in [[Volokolamsk]] in 16 November 2016 and in Russia in 24 November 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.gazeta.ru/culture/2016/11/16/a_10338035.shtml|title=28 самураев|website=Gazeta.ru|accessdate=6 October 2017}} The plot was written by Andrey Shalopa in 2009, and the production team took their [[Trailer (promotion)|teaser trailer]] of the film to Boomstarter [[crowdfunding]] platform, seeking co-financiers. "It will be a film about Soviet heroes. We will describe the battle near Dubosekovo, which went down in history as the deed of Panfilov's 28 men". The crowdfunding campaign was successful, and the film raised 3 million rubles out of planned 300 thousands.{{cite web|url=https://boomstarter.ru/projects/36881/28_panfilovtsev|title=28 панфиловцев - Boomstarter|date=2 December 2016|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=6 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202210826/https://boomstarter.ru/projects/36881/28_panfilovtsev|archivedate=2 December 2016|df=}} By the time of the premiere the film raised 34,746 million rubles.{{cite web|url=http://28panfilovcev.com/payments.php|title=28 панфиловцев|date=2 December 2016|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=6 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202210525/http://28panfilovcev.com/payments.php|archivedate=2 December 2016|df=}} In May 2014 Gaijin Entertainment, Russian game development company known for its game [[War Thunder]] joined the funding.{{cite web|url=http://www.trud.ru/article/18-11-2016/1344147_28_panfilovtsev_grom_vojny.html|title=«28 панфиловцев»: гром войны|website=Trud.ru|accessdate=6 October 2017}} {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NE-39Mguh1k|title=The teaser of the film Panfilov’s 28 Men|date=|publisher=[[War Thunder]]|accessdate=}} In December 2014 the film won a grant of 30 million [[Russian ruble|rubles]] from [[Ministry of Culture (Russia)|Russian Ministry of Culture]], and later the Ministry of Culture and Sport of Kazakhstan added another $287 thousand. Collecting money, producing and renting the film accompanied a vigorous discussion of its historical authenticity in the blogosphere and the media. The picture was positively received by the spectators, having collected in the [[Flag of the Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] 384 million rubles and becoming the best film of the year according to the results of the [[Russian Public Opinion Research Center|VTsIOM]] poll.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} ==Plot== USSR, late November 1941. Based on the account by reporter Vasiliy Koroteev that appeared in the [[Red Army]]'s newspaper, ''[[Krasnaya Zvezda]]'', shortly after the [[Battle of Moscow]], this is the story of [[Panfilov's Twenty-Eight Guardsmen|Panifilov's Twenty-Eight]], a group of twenty-eight soldiers of the Red Army's [[316th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|316th Rifle Division]], under the command of General Ivan Panfilov, that stopped the advance on Moscow of a column of fifty-four German tanks of the 11th Panzer Division for several days. Though armed only with standard issue [[Mosin-Nagant]] infantry rifles and DP and PM-M1910 machine guns, all useless against tanks, and with wholly inadequate [[RPG-40]] [[anti-tank grenade]]s and [[PTRD-41]] anti-tank rifles, they fight tirelessly and defiantly, with uncommon bravery and unwavering dedication, to protect Moscow and their Motherland. ==Cast== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2017}} Due to the peculiarities of the crowd-budgeting budget, the casting took a long time. The first confirmed actor was Yakov Kucherevskiy, who played Sergeant Dobrobabin - he agreed to withdraw two years before filming. The most recent confirmed Aleksey Morozov for the role of political instructor Klochkov - one day before the start of the shooting period. Panfilov's division was formed in the [[Kazakh SSR]], the company included many Kazakhs, so many actors of Oriental appearance were required in the crowd - Shalope's team turned to the national diasporas of Moscow, [[St. Petersburg]] and [[Ivanovo]]. In general, the team consisted of 360 participants, and in total the project involved up to 700 people. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" ! Actors !! Role |- | Yakov Kucherevskiy ([[:commons:File:Kucherevski playing Dobrobabin Panfilov 28 men.jpg|image]]) || Ivan Dobrobabin, Sergeant |- | Aleksey Morozov ([[:commons:File:Politruk Klochkov panfilovs 28 menbw (cropped).jpg|image]]) || Vasiliy Klochkov, Political instructor |- | Sergey Agafonov ([[:commons:File:Sergei Agafonov face.jpg|image]]) || Grigoriy Bezrodnyh, Red Army |- | Aleksandr Ustyugov ([[:commons:File:Alexander Ustyugov 28 panfilovcev.jpg|image]]) || Ivan Moskalenko, Red Army |- | Oleg Fyodorov ([[:commons:File:Oleg Fedorov as Shemyakin bw.jpg|image]]) || Grigoriy Shemyakin, Red Army |- | Andrey Nekrasov || Illarion Vasiljev, Red Army |- | Nikolai Klyamchuk || Grigoriy Petrenko, Red Army |- | Mikhail Pshenko ([[:commons:File:Pshenko Mikhail.jpg|image]]) || Pyotr Dutov, Red Army |- | Dmitriy Murashev ([[:commons:File:Dmitry Murashev.jpg|image]]) || Grigoriy Konkin, Red Army |- | Anton Paderin ([[:commons:File:Anton Paderin2 bw.jpg|image]]) || Pyoter Emtsov, Red Army |- | Dmitriy Girev ([[:commons:File:Girev Dmitriy.jpg|image]]) || Yakov Bondarenko, Red Army |- | Vitaliy Kovalenko ([[:commons:File:Kovalenko Vitaliy.jpg|image]]) || Ivan Shepetkov, Red Army |- | Anton Filipenko || Nikolay Trofimov, Red Army |- | Amadu Mamadakov ([[:commons:File:Mamadakov Amadu.jpg|image]]) || Alikbay Kosaev, Red Army |- | Azamat Nigmanov ([[:commons:File:Nigmatov Azamat.jpg|image]]) || Musabek Sengirbaev, Red Army |- | Aleksandr Plaksin || Abram Kryuchkov, Red Army |- | Maksim Belborodov ([[:commons:File:Maxim Belbrodov.jpg|image]]) || Dmitriy Kaleynikov, Red Army |- | Oleg Senchenko || Gabriil Mitin, Red Army |- | Pavel Goncharov ([[:commons:File:Oleg Senchenko.jpg|image]]) || Ivan Natarov, Red Army |} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" ! Actors !! Role |- | Ivan Efremov || Nikita Mitchenko, Red Army |- | Nikolai Ivanov || Nikolay Belashev, Red Army |- | Vladimir Zaharenko || Nikolay Maksimov, Red Army |- | Dmitriy Tsutskin || Nikolay Ananjev, Red Army |- | Andrey Bodrenkov ([[:commons:File:Andrey Bodrenkov.jpg|image]]) || Ivan Shadrin, Red Army |- | Askar Tleugobilov ([[:commons:File:Askar Tleugobilov.jpg|image]]) || Duishenkul Shopokov, Red Army |- | di. Kim Druzhinin || Daniil Kozhebergenov, Red Army |- | Mark Ovchinnikov || Dmitriy Timofeev |- | Aleksey Longin || Pavel Gundilovich, captain, company commander |- | Anton Kuznetsov ([[:commons:File:Anton Kuznetsov phone bw.jpg|image]]) || Y.M.Reshetnikov, major, commander of battalion |- | di. Andrey Shalopa ([[:commons:File:Shalyopa actor.jpg|image]]) || Vasiliy Ugryumov, Lieutenant |- | Dmitriy Sutyrin || Pyotr Ignatyev, senior lieutenant |- | Ivan Batarev || artillery commander |- | Nikita Ostrikov || signalman in headquarters |- | Aleksey Kashnikov || signaller |- | Kirill Kuznetsov || observer of the KP battalion |- | Lidiya Milyuzina || girl |- | Maksim Abrosimov || Panfilov's |- | Stanislav Lyamtsev || |} {{col-end}} ==Production== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2017}} ==Filming == [[File:28 Panfilovcev.jpg|thumb|220px|Actors and members of the crew of the film, in November 2013]] In the process of filming, the picture operators used the following documents: storyboard, director's script, operator's table and tank battle scheme. The battle scheme contained the exact location of the tanks and the camera at different times, and the operator's table described what technique to use in what scenes. Such careful preparation allowed the team to work in winter conditions and with a short daylight. The directors wanted to use a minimum of 3D animation and take as many effects as possible on the camera. The first experiments they conducted, moving primitive toy tanks the size of a matchbox on the sheets with the help of ropes. These experiments have shown that using reduced models of tanks will create the right level of realism. As a contractor for the creation of special effects, Scandinava studio, previously specializing in commercials and having no experience with large films, was chosen. Specialists from Scandinava performed experiments on high-speed shooting and interested Druzhinin and Shalopu with his clip "Oil", in which a column of combustible liquid was rotating and ignited without the use of 3D animation. To work on the film, the studio expanded the staff from six to 28 people. [[File:Tanks 28 panfilov's men pavilion.jpg|thumb|220px|Pavilion "Lenfilm"]] [[File:Green tanks 28 panfilovs men 12x8.jpg|thumb|220px|Full-scale shooting models 1: 1]] To create personnel with tanks, studio specialists used the old technology of combined shooting-special effect. On the field, full-size wooden models of tanks, covered with green cloth, were used in the field, which the workers moved around the field on a sleigh. Then the surveyors made measurements of the landscape, and Scandinava recreated the battlefield at a scale of 1:16 in the studio and photographed all the scenes with detailed models of tanks, reduced by 16 times. To create a winter atmosphere in the film (snow, blizzard, the sky changing in the film's drama), the consequences of the attacks (smoke, ash), and to amplify gun shots and some explosions, Scandinava decided not to use the traditional approach using CGI ([[Computer-generated imagery]], The letters "computer-generated images"), instead taking real natural effects on the camera. Shooting on the nature, tanks and natural effects were collected by layers on the computer in one single image. This approach required a certain technique of filming. In order to move the toy tank were like moving the present, it was necessary to shoot it four times faster, and then slow down the received frames. The camera, accordingly, had to be moved four times faster than on the field, which can not be done with hands. Therefore, in the pavilion shootings for camera control, the operators used the robotic arm KUKA Agilus, provided and programmed with the help of specialists from the Research [[Russian State Scientific Center for Robotics and Technical Cybernetics|Research Institute of Robotics]]. For close-up shots, a full-size mock-up of the PzKpfw IV tank was built, the cabin of which was recreated on Lenfilm as a separate capsule on the springs, which made it possible to achieve realistic pitching during shooting. Currently, the layout is kept in the Museum of the Karelian isthmus in the Vyborg. The whole film was shot on the camera Arri Alexa (English) Russian, except for tanks, where because of the size required the apparatus of the company Red. Optometry used a spherical lens Illumina of the St. Petersburg plant "LOMO" - according to the operator, this solution allowed to smooth out the effect of the "excessively high-quality" image, which is inherent in all modern cameras. ===Music=== [[File:Creation of music in Panvilovs 28 men.ogg|thumb|Description of the process of writing the music for the film.]] Sound for the film was recorded and reduced to the technical base of the studio "[[Nevafilm]]". Mikhail Kostylev, famous for his soundtracks for computer games, took up writing music for the film. According to the composer, he sought to convey a sense of pride in the Victory and the feat, creating an epic musical background in which the drama would remain. The leitmotif of most compositions is the theme "Eternal Flame", which Kostylev wrote at an early stage of the production of the film. The soundtrack was recorded after the presentation of the video, with the first score for all instruments was recorded using a [[MIDI]] editor. This allowed the director to immediately appreciate the approximate sound of the music, its mood and tempo. Then, using a metronome, individual instrument parts, vocals, chorus and parts were recorded, in which a whole orchestra was involved. Choral parts are performed by vocalists of the Moscow Synodal Choir under the direction of the Honored Artist of Russia Aleksei Puzankov, instrumental musicians of the ensemble of soloists of the [[Saint Petersburg Academic Symphony Orchestra|Academic Symphony Orchestra of the Philharmonic]]. ==Reception== ===Government support=== Apart from its crowdfunding budget, Panfilov’s 28 Men was produced with backing from the culture ministries of Russia and Kazakhstan. Russian culture minister [[Vladimir Medinsky]] praised the planned release of the film, telling the upper chamber of Russia's parliament that the production reflected the country's interest in patriotic films.{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/news/russian-archives-cast-doubt-on-legends-of-soviet-war-heroes-48026|title=Russian Archives Cast Doubt on Legends of Soviet War Heroes|website=Themoscowtimes.com|access-date=2017-05-21|language=en}} Referencing criticism over the historical accuracy of the Soviet legend that formed the basis of the movie, he stated that the story is "a sacred legend that shouldn't be interfered with. People that do that are filthy scum." ===Box office=== Rent a film in Russia was held from November 24 to December 26, 2016. The volume of the total ticket office for the first weekend was 180,559,249 rubles. In Russia and [[Belarus]] at the beginning of the film the film yielded only to the film ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]''. According to the report of the [[Cinema Foundation of Russia|Cinema Foundation]], at the 48th week (from 24 to 30 November), Russian cinemas were visited by 3.4 million spectators, of which every fourth spectator chose "28 panfilovtsev", and the fees amounted to 209.8 million rubles. The fund reports that the percentage of morning and afternoon shows was at evening level. That is, the film attracted a wide audience - and the adult viewer, and schoolchildren with students. In total, up to November 30, 36,616 sessions were held in Russia, which were attended by 878,944 spectators. The fees in [[Kazakhstan]] amounted to 61.3 million tenge. On December 26, the film became available for purchase in online stores, and on January 27, 2017, it was released on DVD and Blu-ray. By mid-January, box office fees amounted to about 366.6 million rubles in Russia, and all in the [[Flag of the Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] countries the film collected 385 million rubles. ===Critical reception=== ''Panfilov's 28 Men'' holds an aggregate score of 7.1/10 in user reviews on IMDB.{{cite web|title=Panfilov's 28 (2016)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5207204/|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=2017-05-21}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Panfilov's 28 Men}} * {{official website|http://28panfilovcev.com/en/index.php}} {{en icon}} * {{IMDb title|5207204}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Panfilov's 28 Men}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:Russian-language films]] [[Category:2010s historical films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s war films]] [[Category:2010s action films]] [[Category:Crowdfunding]] [[Category:Russian historical films]] [[Category:Russian drama films]] [[Category:Russian war films]] [[Category:Russian action films]] [[Category:Films set in Moscow]] [[Category:Films set in 1941]] [[Category:Films shot in Moscow]] [[Category:War drama films]] [[Category:World War II films]] [[Category:Films set in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Eastern Front of World War II films]] [[Category:Films based on short fiction]] [[Category:Sequel films]] [[Category:Films about armoured warfare]] [[Category:Drama films based on actual events]] [[Category:War films based on actual events]] [[Category:World War II films based on actual events]] [[Category:Russian films]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Privateer Press Inc. | logo = File:Privateer_Press_logo.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Miniature wargaming]] | founder = {{ubl|[[Brian Snoddy]]|Matt Staroscik|[[Matt Wilson (artist)|Matt Wilson]]}} | foundation = {{Start date|2000}} | location_city = [[Bellevue, Washington]] | location_country = United States | key_people = {{ubl|Sherry Yeary ([[President (corporate title)|President]])|Matt Wilson ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])}} | products = {{ubl|''[[Iron Kingdoms]]''|''[[Warmachine]]''|''[[Hordes (game)|Hordes]]''}} | owner = Matt Wilson<ref name=about>{{cite web|title=About Privateer Press|url=http://privateerpress.com/company/about-privateer-press|website=Privateer Press|accessdate=September 8, 2015}}</ref> | website = {{URL|privateerpress.com}} }} '''Privateer Press''' is a [[role-playing game]], [[miniature wargaming|miniature wargame]], [[acrylic paint]], [[board game]] and [[card game]] production and publishing studio. Privateer Press is based in [[Bellevue, Washington]], [[United States]], where they have their headquarters and American factory/distribution center. They have also licensed a factory in the [[United Kingdom]] to increase production capacity for worldwide markets.
The company's signature products are [[Warmachine]] and [[Hordes (game)|Hordes]], tabletop miniatures-based war games with a [[steampunk]]/magical aesthetic. Noted webcomic creators and game critics [[Jerry Holkins]] and [[Mike Krahulik]] of [[Penny Arcade]] are fans of Warmachine.<ref>{{cite web|last=Krahilik|first=Mike|title=Corvis Table|url=http://www.penny-arcade.com/2011/09/12/corvis-table|publisher=penny-arcade.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref> Privateer Press used to publish a house magazine called No Quarter.<ref>https://privateerpress.com/no-quarter-prime/farewell-to-no-quarter-prime</ref>
==History== In 2000, [[Matt Wilson (artist)|Matt Wilson]] formed Privateer Press with friend [[Brian Snoddy]] and writer Matt Staroscik to publish their own [[D20 System|d20]] books.<ref name=about /><ref name="designers">{{Cite book|author=Shannon Appelcline|title=Designers & Dragons|publisher=Mongoose Publishing|year=2011| isbn= 978-1-907702-58-7}}</ref>{{rp|392}} [[Mike McVey]] joined the partnership early on as Miniatures Director. Wilson and Snoddy produced the covers and interior art for Privateer's first [[Iron Kingdoms]] adventures published in 2001.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|392}} The company is currently owned by Wilson due to the departure of Snoddy and McVey.
After their first five RPG books, Privateer's next publication was ''[[Warmachine|Warmachine: Prime]]'' (2003), a miniatures combat game set in the Iron Kingdoms.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|392}} In 2009 Privateer announced a partnership with WhiteMoon Dreams intended to bring ''Warmachine'' to video game consoles.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|393}}
On October 20, 2017, Privateer Press created Black Anchor Heavy Industries, an in-house production team to create huge based models while limiting production costs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://privateerpress.com/community/privateer-insider/insider-10-20-2017|title=Insider 10-20-2017 {{!}} Privateer Press|website=privateerpress.com|language=en-US|access-date=October 26, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2018 after 12 years of publication Privateer Press announced it would be ending publication of their bi-monthly magazine, "No Quarter".
== Products == The company's products are distinguished by the quality of their art, production values, and game play.<ref>{{cite web|last=Platt|first=Chuck|title=Tabletop Review: No Quarter#36|url=http://diehardgamefan.com/2011/11/16/tabletop-review-no-quarter-36/|publisher=diehardgamefan.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref> They have received many game industry awards, including six [[Origins Award]]s<ref>{{cite web|title=Origins Award Winners|url=http://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Origins_Awards#toc5|publisher=boardgamegeek.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2005 Origins Winners Announced|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/8935.html|publisher=icv2.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref> and numerous [[ENnies]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Privateer Press List of Awards|url=http://wolfgameshop.com/forum/viewtopic.php?p=5481&sid=cc658aa45e4c392f7fe6850763059aa0|publisher=wolfgameshop.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Awards|url=http://privateerpress.com/search/node/awards|publisher=privateerpress.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref>
===List of titles=== *''[[Formula P3]] ('''P'''rivateer '''P'''ress '''P'''aint)'' acrylic paint *''Privateer Press Masterworks'' painted statues *''[[Iron Kingdoms]]'' [[steampunk]] fantasy universe **''Iron Kingdoms Role-Playing Games'' **''Iron Kingdoms Adventure Board Games'' **''[[Warmachine]]'' & ''[[Hordes (game)|Hordes]]'' miniature wargames **''[[Grind_(board_game)|Grind]]'' miniature sports game **''[[High Command (game)|High Command]]'' [[deck-building game|deck-building]] card games *''[[Bodgers (Privateer Press)|Bodgers]]'' family board and card games **''[[Zombies Keep Out]]'' **''[[BodgerMania]]'' **''[[Heap (game)|Heap]]'' **''[[Infernal Contraption]]'' **''[[Scrappers (game)|Scrappers]]'' *''[[Level 7 (game)|Level 7]]'' science-fiction board games **''Level 7 [Escape]'' **''Level 7 [Omega Protocol]'' **''Level 7 [Invasion]'' *''[[Monsterpocalypse]]'' collectible miniatures game **''[[Voltron|Monsterpocalypse: Voltron]]'' licensed standalone set
==Charitable contributions== The company has been a longtime supporter of [[Child's Play (charity)|Child's Play]], a charity which gives toys and games to sick kids in children's hospitals around the world. In 2009, Privateer Press bid on and won an item at the annual Child's Play Holiday auction, donated by [[Harmonix]], which brought them the rights to commission a downloadable song track for the ''[[Rock Band]]'' game. The resulting song "Warmachine," written by Jerry Holkins, premiered at [[Penny Arcade Expo|Pax]] 2010 and was made available for download that fall. All proceeds from the track are also donated to Child's Play.<ref>{{cite web|last=Holkins|first=Jerry|title=warmachine-precipice|url=http://penny-arcade.com/2010/10/06/warmachine-precipice|publisher=penny-arcade.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Polo|first=Susana|title=PAX Is Awesome #543: If You’re Good at Rock Band, You Might Open the Omegathon|url=http://www.geekosystem.com/pax-warmachine-rock-band-song/|publisher=geekosystem.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Matt|title=Insider 9/8/2010|url=http://privateerpress.com/community/privateer-insider/insider-9/8/2010|publisher=privateerpress.com|accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref>
